title: CTRL0000050581 - Transcribed Interview of Arthur Schwartz, (February 14, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The deposition in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 1:59 p.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
So it is 1:59 p.m., we'll go on the record.
This is a deposition of Arthur Schwartz conducted by the House
Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol
Mr. Schwartz is with us by Webex, and I just ask you to state your full name and
spell your last name for the record, please.
And if you wouldn't mind, if you could please just raise
your right hand, we'll have the court reporter swear you in to get started.
Do you solemnly declare and affirm under the penalty of perjury
that the testimony you are about to give will be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing
This will be a staff-led deposition and members of the committee may, of course,
join and choose to also ask questions.
on the Webex, but they might pop in from time to time.
I'll note now that there are no members who are
And if they do, I'll stop and
I'm a senior investigative counsel on the staff.
I'm the only attorney who's on today, and so, otherwise we just have staff who are
assisting with the deposition, and then also, the court reporters that you just saw.
So we'll follow the House deposition rules that we've provided to you and your
counsel previously with the subpoena and under those rules you are permitted to have
So at this time, I'm going to ask your attorneys to please announce themselves for
the record, and note that we'll wait until the end of my introductory comments as I
believe Mr. -- one of your attorneys has an objection to place on the record.
now if they could just state their names.
On behalf of Arthur Schwartz, we have the law firm of Abel
Bean Law today, Jared Burns and myself, Daniel Bean.
Now, Mr. Schwartz, under the House deposition rules, neither committee
members nor staff may discuss the substance of your testimony that you provide today
one what we discussed here today.
You, of course, are free to tell anyone or no
That right is entirely yours and your choice to make.
Before we begin, I'll just go over a few ground rules.
reporter, as you've seen, who is transcribing the record of this deposition.
joining us by Webex and they are also video recording the deposition.
Please wait until each question is completed before you begin your response, and
I'll do the same and wait for you to finish before I move on to my next question.
just to keep the record clear.
The reporter is not able to record nonverbal responses.
head or nod your head, I'll just follow up to ask you to say yes or no.
acronym or a name that I'm unfamiliar with, I might stop you to ask you to spell that for
the record, and that's just so the record is clear.
Now, we ask that you provide complete answers based on the best of your
And if the question is not clear, just say so and I'll do my best to restate it
If you don't know the answer, just say so.
If you or Mr. Bean need to take a break either to talk between yourselves or just
for comfort, just let us know.
We'll go off camera, go on mute.
You either can talk in private and come back on when you're ready.
I don't think that this will take more than, you know, a couple of hours.
want to just power through, I'm fine to do that, too.
But if you want to take a break,
Now, throughout the deposition, I have a staff member who's not with me, but
will flash exhibits up for you up on the screen.
so hopefully you've been able to look through those.
I shared those with Mr. Bean on Friday,
Several of them came from you; several of them came from other witnesses, but
when they're up on the screen, I'll announce them by number and take whatever time
you need to look at them to familiarize yourself with them before you answer any
And if we need to zoom in, just tell us.
It can be a bit hard to navigate virtually.
I also see that Mr. Raskin has joined us.
So I'll say, thank you, sir, for being here.
We're still going over the ground rules for the deposition.
So what I'm going to do is show you, Mr. Schwartz, just the first
exhibit, which is the subpoena, just so you can see how it'll be displayed.
And so right there, you can see -- can you see that well enough?
or do you need it closer for you to be able to look at these documents?
So you may only refuse to answer a question to preserve a privilege recognized by
If you refuse to answer a question based on a privilege, staff may
either proceed with the deposition or seek a ruling from the chairman of the committee
And if the chairman overrules such an objection, you are required to
At this time, I understand that Mr. Bean is going to make an objection on your
behalf for the record, so I'll pause so he can do that.
So Mr. Schwartz objects to the instant deposition proceedings as the select
committee has not properly and duly authorized, in accordance with House Resolution
503, Section 2 Alpha, 117th Congress 2021, as it is not compromised of 13 members, five
of whom were appointed after consultation with the minority leader.
Mr. Schwartz also objects to the instant deposition proceedings as the subpoena
purporting to compel his appearance does not further a valid legislative purpose ancillary
to the legislative authority, but, rather, serves a quintessentially law enforcement
purposes reserved to the authority of the executive branch of the United States, to wit,
investigate facts, circumstances, and causes, as well as expose and punish criminal
and are devoid of any legislative purpose.
All of these are proffered objectives of the select committee
Mr. Schwartz also objects to the instant deposition proceedings as to the
subpoena reporting to compel Mr. Schwartz' appearance violates his constitutional rights,
including, but not limited to, his First Amendment right to freedom of speech, freedom of
assembly, his Fourth Amendment right to be free of unreasonable search and seizure, his
Fourth Amendment right that warrants be issued only upon a finding of probable cause,
and finally, his Fifth Amendment right to due process of law.
Finally, Mr. Schwartz, objects to this proceeding as a violation of the separation of
And, lastly, notwithstanding the aforementioned objections, Mr. Schwartz
submits to the examination under oath before the select committee as an American
citizen, except where specifically objected to during these proceedings.
Mr. Bean, thank you for that.
And Mr. Schwartz, I note those
response to those except to note, for the record, that the committee does not agree with
the objections, but understand that you are still willing to go forward today, which we
I won't go through the responses of the committee in

the committee, that it is unlawful to deliberately provide false information to Congress.
And since this deposition is under oath, providing false information could result in
criminal penalties to include for perjury or providing false statements.
Do you understand all of that?
Any questions before we get started, whether from you, Mr.
So just to get started, just to understand a little bit about your background,
And what State do you live in?
And what do you do for a living?
And has that been your career for several years now?
And do you have a current company that you work for, or a
And how long have you had that company, roughly?
And just for the record, is it right that it's A-x-i-u-m, Axium?
I can't tell you exactly when it was formed.
And did you serve as a government employee within the
So you're in the private sector with Axium the entire time he served in

Understood, but you're aware that he does provide advice whether paid for

And do you know a gentleman by the name of Taylor Budowich,
And how do you know Mr. Budowich?
I don't remember who introduced us, but through, you know, Republican

And do you know Caroline Wren?
And how did you know Ms. Wren?
I couldn't tell you how I met her.
But same question as I asked about Mr. Budowich, did you know her, at

Now, did you have an official role in the 2020 re-election campaign that
And after Election Day, so after November 3rd of 2020, did you work for or

I'm going to focus on mid-December of 2020 through January 6th.
you still in Texas in that time frame?
Were you living in that State?
Where were you living during those few weeks?
Now, just talk briefly about the production of documents you

witness what the process was to try to identify those documents.
Did you have any hard-copy files that you went through of any documents to look
through, or you don't keep hard copies?
And it looks like from the documents you did produce, they look to be emails
I have no such hard copy records.
that you would've either sent or received through Axium Advisers account.
I couldn't tell -- I gave access and control over my phone and my email to my

So in terms of the cell phone you said you provided it, is that
just with the number that ends i n - a s the phone number, the last four digits?
Now, included in the materials you produced, by my count -- and Mr. Bean

know you exchanged text messages with, say, Ms. Pierson or Mr. Budowich about this
So I'll just ask -- and we do

And so I didn't see any text messages of any sort.
with those folks or others from back in January of 2021?
Is there a particular reason why?
That's -- it's an option on the iPhone that I selected.
And -- at the time we're talking about, so, again, November 2020 through
My phone is not set up to store anything after 30 days.
So they just sort of been deleted in the normal course?
January of 2021, were you using any other messaging apps, such as Signal or WhatsApp or
Telegram or Parler, just as a general matter?
course on the regular basis whatever messages you would have sent in that time frame?
Do you know whether you delete those just in the normal
The apps that I used automatically delete at a set time frame, so, yes, they

that rally on the 6th, do you remember how you first learned about or first started talking
about the preparation for the event on the 6th?
I mean, that's really the core of it.
Let's go back for a second.
And so, in the weeks or days leading up to
I was not involved in the preparation, so I don't
I didn't mean to suggest you were.
I just meant to say that as it was being

believe, in Breitbart on January 3rd about expected speakers at the event on the 6th?

that you were aware of, at least, by January 3rd?

I saw it on social media.

In other words, he was holding himself out as being affiliated with that?
I seem to recall that that was my impression at the time.
about what I knew back then, correct?
Correct, as best you can remember.

Just from a comms perspective, I never found the things that he was saying
to be particularly helpful to party politics.
I don't have any specific recollection of what
things, but I just didn't view him as being a -- contributing in a positive way.
down on that first page -- so this is January 3rd at 7:28 p.m., and you write to Ms.
